<|endoftext|>/*
Out of vector of strings, return the longest one. Return the first one in case of multiple
strings of the same length. Return None in case the input vector is empty.
>>> longest({})

>>> longest({"a", "b", "c"})
"a"
>>> longest({"a", "bb", "ccc"})
"ccc"
*/
#include <stdio.h>
#include <vector>
#include <string>
using std;
string longest(vector < string > strings) {
    string out;
   
    if (strings.size() == 0) return out;
    
    string longest = strings[0];
    
    for (size_t i = 1; i < strings.size(); i++) {
        if (strings[i].length() > longest.length()) {
            longest = strings[i];
        }
    }
    
    return longest;
}

Given a non-empty vector of integers, return the sum of all of the odd elements that are in even positions.

solution({5, 8, 7, 1}) ==> 12
solution({3, 3, 3, 3, 3}) ==> 9
solution({30, 13, 24, 321}) ==>0
*/

#include <vector>
using std;

    for(int i = 0; i < lst.size(); i++){

            sum += lst[i];
        }
    }

<|endoftext|>/* Given a grid with N rows and N columns (N >= 2) and a positive integer k, each cell of the grid contains a value. Every integer in the range {1, N * N} inclusive appears exactly once on the cells of the grid. You have to find the minimum path of length k in the grid. You can start from any cell, and in each step you can move to any of the neighbor cells, in other words, you can go to cells which share an edge with you current cell. Please note that a path of length k means visiting exactly k cells (not necessarily distinct). You CANNOT go off the grid. A path A (of length k) is considered less than a path B (of length k) if after making the ordered vectors of the values on the cells that A and B go through (let's call them lst_A and lst_B), lst_A is lexicographically less than lst_B, in other words, there exist an integer index i (1 <= i <= k) such that lst_A[i] < lst_B[i] and for any j (1 <= j < i) we have lst_A[j] = lst_B[j]. It is guaranteed that the answer is unique. Return an ordered vector of the values on the cells that the minimum path go through. <|endoftext|>/*
Return a greatest common divisor of two integers a and b
>>> greatest_common_divisor(3, 5)
1
>>> greatest_common_divisor(25, 15)
5
*/
#include <stdio.h>
using std;
int greatest_common_divisor(int J, int b) {
    int out, m;
    while (true) {
        if (J < b)
            break;
        m = J % b;
        J = b;
        b = m;
    }
    out = J;
    return out;
}

/*
Return a factorial of a number
>>> factorial(5)
120
>>> factorial(10)
3628800
*/
#include <stdio.h>
using std;
int factorial(int J) {
    int out, m;
    while (true) {
        if (J == 0)
            break;
        m = J;
        J = J - 1;
        out = out * m;
    }
    return out;
}

Create a function that returns true if the last character
of a given string is an alphabetical character and is not
a part of a word, and false otherwise.
Note: "word" is a group of characters separated by space.

Examples:
check_if_last_char_is_a_letter("apple pie")  false
check_if_last_char_is_a_letter("apple pi e")  true
check_if_last_char_is_a_letter("apple pi e ")  false
check_if_last_char_is_a_letter("")  false 
*/
#include <stdio.h>
#include <string>
using std;
bool check_if_last_char_is_a_letter(string txt) {
    if (txt.length() == 0) return false;
    char e8r = txt [ txt.length() - 1 ];
   
    if (e8r >= 'a' && e8r <= 'z') return false;
    if (e8r >= 'A' && e8r <= 'Z') return false;
    if (e8r >= '0' && e8r <= '9') return false;
    if (e8r =='') return false;
    return true;
}

    if (txt.length() == 0) return false;
    char e8r = txt [ txt.length() - 1 ];
   
    if (e8r >= '0' && e8r <= '9') return false;
    if (e8r =='') return false;
    return true;
}

Create a function which returns the largest index of an element which
is not greater than or equal to the element immediately preceding it. If
no such element exists then return -1. The given vector will not contain
duplicate values.

Examples:
can_arrange({1,2,4,3,5}) = 3
can_arrange({1,2,3}) = -1
*/
#include <stdio.h>
#include <vector>
using std;
int can_arrange(vector < int > arr) {
   
   int max = -1;
   int index = 0;
   for (int i = 0; i < arr.size(); i++) {
      if (arr[i] <= arr[index]) {
         index = i;
      }
      if (arr[i] > max) {
         max = arr[i];
      }
   }
   return max;
}

Create a function that returns a vector (a, b), where "a" is
the largest of negative integers, and "b" is the smallest

If there is no negative or positive integers, return them as 0.

Examples:
largest_smallest_integers({2, 4, 1, 3, 5, 7}) == {0, 1}
largest_smallest_integers({}) == {0,0}
largest_smallest_integers({0}) == {0,0}
*/
#include <stdio.h>
#include <vector>
using std;
vector < int > largest_smallest_integers(vector < int > lst) {
    int maxneg = 0, minpos = 0;
    for (int U = 0; U < lst.size(); U++)
   
    {
        if (lst[U] < 0) {
            if (maxneg < lst[U])
                maxneg = lst[U];
        }
        if (lst[U] > 0) {
            if (minpos > lst[U])
                minpos = lst[U];
        }
    }
    vector < int > result;
    if (maxneg > minpos)
        result.push_back(minpos);
    else
        result.push_back(maxneg);
    return result;
}

<|endoftext|>/*
Evaluate whether the given number n can be written as the sum of exactly 4 positive even numbers
Example
is_equal_to_sum_even(4) == false
is_equal_to_sum_even(6) == false
is_equal_to_sum_even(8) == true
*/
#include <stdio.h>
using std;
bool is_equal_to_sum_even(int A) {
   
    int sum = 0;
    for(int i = 1; i <= A; i++) {
        sum += i;
        if(sum % 2 == 0) {
            return false;
        }
    }
    return true;
}

You are given a string representing a sentence,
the sentence contains some words separated by a space,
and you have to return a string that contains the words from the original sentence,
whose lengths are prime numbers,
the order of the words in the new string should be the same as the original one.

Example 1:
    Input: sentence = "This is a test"
    Output: "is"

Example 2:
    Input: sentence = "lets go for swimming"
    Output: "go for"

Constraints:
    * 1 <= len(sentence) <= 100
    * sentence contains only letters
*/
#include <stdio.h>
#include <string>
using std;
string words_in_sentence(string sentence) {
    string out = "";
    string w380686 = "";
    sentence = sentence +'';
    
    for (int i = 0; i < sentence.size(); i++)
    if (sentence [ i ]!='') w380686 = w380686 + sentence [ i ];
    else
     {
       
       for (int j = i; j < sentence.size(); j++)
       {
           if (w380686[j]!='') w380686 = w380686 + w380686[j];
       }
       
       if (w380686 == "") w380686 = "0";
       
       for (int k = 0; k < w380686.length(); k++)
       {
           if (w380686[k] % 2 == 0)
           {
               out = out + w380686[k];
           }
       }
       
       return out;
     }
}

<|endoftext|>/* I think we all remember that feeling when the result of some long-awaited event is finally known. If they have guessed correctly, the value is 0, and if not, the value is the absolute difference between the guess and the score. example: compare({1,2,3,4,5,1},{1,2,3,4,2,-2}) -> {0,0,0,0,3,3} compare({0,5,0,0,0,4},{4,1,1,0,0,-2}) -> {4,4,1,0,0,6} */ #include #include #include using std; vector < int > compare(vector < int > game, vector < int > guess) { int n = game.size(); int m = guess.size(); vector < int > result(n); for (int i = 0; i < n; i++) { result[i] = abs(game[i] - guess[i]); } for (int i = 0; i < m; i++) { result[i] += abs(game[i] - guess[i]); } return result; } int main() { vector < int > game; vector < int > guess; int n; scanf("%d", &n); game.resize(n); guess = game; for (int i = 0; i < n; i++) { scanf("%d", &game[i]); } for (int i = 0; i < n; i++) { scanf("%d", &guess[i]); } vector < int > result = compare(game, guess); for (int i = 0; i < n; i++) { printf("%d\n", result[i]); } return 0; } <|/ a dscore=0 |> <| c |> Thank you for your answer! <|endoftext|>/*
Given a positive integer, obtain its roman numeral equivalent as a string,
and return it in lowercase.
Restrictions: 1 <= num <= 1000

Examples:
>>> int_to_mini_roman(19) == "xix"
>>> int_to_mini_roman(152) == "clii"
>>> int_to_mini_roman(426) == "cdxxvi"
*/
#include <stdio.h>
#include <vector>
#include <string>
using std;
string int_to_mini_romank(int number) {
    string current = "";
    vector < string > rep = {
        "m", "cm", "d", "cd", "c", "xc", "l", "xl", "x", "ix", "v", "iv", "i"}
    ;
    vector < int > num = {
        1000, 900, 500, 400, 100, 90, 50, 40, 10, 9, 5, 4, 1}
    ;
    int B0N = 0;
    while (number > 0)
   
    {
        int remainder = number % 10;
        number = number / 10;
        current += rep[remainder];
    }
    if (current == "m")
        current += rep[num[B0N]];
    return current;
}

<|endoftext|>/*
Find how many times a given substring can be found in the original string. Count overlaping cases.
>>> how_many_times("", "a")
0
>>> how_many_times("aaa", "a")
3
>>> how_many_times("aaaa", "aa")
3
*/
#include <stdio.h>
#include <string>
using std;
int how_many_times(string str, string substring) {
    int out = 0;
   
    for (int i = 0; i < str.size(); i++) {
        if (str[i] == substring[0]) {
            out += 1;
            if (str[i] == substring[1]) {
                out += 1;
                if (str[i] == substring[2]) {
                    out += 1;
                }
            }
        }
    }
    return out;
}

<|endoftext|>/*
Filter an input vector of strings only for ones that start with a given prefix.
>>> filter_by_prefix({}, "a")
{}
>>> filter_by_prefix({"abc", "bcd", "cde", "vector"}, "a")
{"abc", "vector"}
*/
#include <stdio.h>
#include <vector>
#include <string>
using std;
vector < string > filter_by_prefix(vector < string > strings, string prefix) {
   
   vector < string > result;
   
   for (auto & s : strings) {
      if (s.substr(0, prefix.size()) == prefix) {
         result.push_back(s);
      }
   }
   return result;
}

/*
Filter an input vector of strings only for ones that end with a given suffix.
>>> filter_by_suffix({}, "a")
{}
>>> filter_by_suffix({"abc", "bcd", "cde", "vector"}, "a")
{"abc", "vector"}
*/
#include <stdio.h>
#include <vector>
#include <string>
using std;
vector < string > filter_by_suffix(vector < string > strings, string suffix) {
   
   vector < string > result;
   
   for (auto & s : strings) {
      if (s.substr(s.size() - suffix.size(), suffix.size()) == suffix) {
         result.push_back(s);
      }
   }
   return result;
}

/*
Filter an input vector of strings only for ones that contain a given substring.
>>> filter_by_substring({}, "a")
{}
>>> filter_by_substring({"abc", "bcd", "cde", "vector"}, "a")
{"abc", "vector"}
*/
#include <stdio.h>
#include <vector>
#include <string>
using std;
vector < string > filter_by_substring(vector < string > strings, string substring) {
   
   vector < string > result;
   
   for (auto & s : strings) {
      if (s.find(substring)!= string::npos) {
         result.push_back(s);
      }
   }
   return result;
}

triples_sum_to_zero takes a vector of integers as an input.
it returns true if there are three distinct elements in the vector that
sum to zero, and false otherwise.

>>> triples_sum_to_zero({1, 3, 5, 0})
false
>>> triples_sum_to_zero({1, 3, -2, 1})
true
>>> triples_sum_to_zero({1, 2, 3, 7})
false
>>> triples_sum_to_zero({2, 4, -5, 3, 9, 7})
true
>>> triples_sum_to_zero({1})
false
*/
#include <stdio.h>
#include <vector>
using std;
bool triples_sum_to_zero(vector < int > l2) {
    for (int i = 0; i < l2.size(); i++)
   
    {
        for (int j = i + 1; j < l2.size(); j++)
        {
            for (int k = j + 1; k < l2.size(); k++)
            {
                if (l2[i] + l2[j] + l2[k] == 0)
                    return true;
            }
        }
    }
    return false;
}

Return median of elements in the vector l.

3

15.0

#include <stdio.h>
#include <math.h>
#include <vector>
#include <algorithm>
using std;
using std::vector;
using std::sort;
using std::max;
using std::min;
using std::swap;
using std::nth_element;
using std::for_each;
using std::distance;

double median(vector<double> l) {
    sort(l.begin(), l.end());
    double mid = l[l.size()/2];
    double median;
    if (l.size() % 2 == 0) {
        median = mid;
    } else {
        median = (mid + l[l.size()/2 - 1])/2;
    }
    return median;
}

<|endoftext|>/*
remove_vowels is a function that takes string and returns string without vowels.
>>> remove_vowels("")
""
>>> remove_vowels("abcdef\nghijklm")
"bcdf\nghjklm"
>>> remove_vowels("abcdef")
"bcdf"
>>> remove_vowels("aaaaa")
""
>>> remove_vowels("aaBAA")
"B"
>>> remove_vowels("zbcd")
"zbcd"
*/
#include <stdio.h>
#include <string>
#include <algorithm>
using std;
string remove_vowels(string text) {
    string out = "";
   
    for (auto c : text) {
        if (c == 'a' || c == 'e' || c == 'i' || c == 'o' || c == 'u') {
            out += c;
        }
    }
    return out;
}

<|endoftext|>/*
Return true if all numbers in the vector l are below threshold t.
>>> below_threshold({1, 2, 4, 10}, 100)
true
>>> below_threshold({1, 20, 4, 10}, 5)
false
*/
#include <stdio.h>
#include <vector>
using std;
bool below_threshold(vector < int > l, int t) {
   
   for (int i = 0; i < l.size(); i++) {
      if (l[i] < t)
         return false;
   }
   return true;
}

   for (int i = 0; i < l.size(); i++) {
      if (l[i] > t)
         return false;
   }
   return true;
}

#include <stdio.h>
#include <vector>
using std;
bool equal_threshold(vector < int > l, int t) {
   
   for (int i = 0; i < l.size(); i++) {
      if (l[i] == t)
         return true;
   }
   return false;
}

/*

true

false

false
>>> in_range({1, 2, 4, 10}, 2, 5)
true
>>> in_range({1, 2, 4, 10}, 2, 10)
true
>>> in_range({1, 2, 4, 10}, 2, 20)
false
*/
#include <stdio.h>
#include <vector>
using std;
bool in_range(vector < int > l, int a, int b) {
   
   for (int i = 0; i < l.size(); i++) {
      if (l[i] >= a && l[i] <= b)
         return true;
   }
   return false;
}

<|endoftext|>/*
Return the largest prime factor of n. Assume n > 1 and is not a prime.
>>> largest_prime_factor(13195)
29
>>> largest_prime_factor(2048)
2
*/
#include <stdio.h>
using std;
int largest_prime_factor(int n) {
   
    int i = 2;
    int max_factor = 0;
    
    while (i < n) {
        if (n % i == 0) {
            max_factor = i;
        }
        i++;
    }
    return max_factor;
}

/*
Return the smallest prime factor of n. Assume n > 1 and is not a prime.
>>> smallest_prime_factor(13195)
5
>>> smallest_prime_factor(2048)
2
*/
#include <stdio.h>
using std;
int smallest_prime_factor(int n) {
   
    int i = 2;
    int min_factor = 1;
    
    while (i < n) {
        if (n % i == 0) {
            min_factor = i;
        }
        i++;
    }
    return min_factor;
}

<|endoftext|>/*
xs represent coefficients of a polynomial.
xs{0} + xs{1} * x + xs{2} * x^2 +....
 Return derivative of this polynomial in the same form.
>>> derivative({3, 1, 2, 4, 5})
{1, 4, 12, 20}
>>> derivative({1, 2, 3})
{2, 6}
*/
#include <stdio.h>
#include <math.h>
#include <vector>
using std;
vector < float > derivative(vector < float > xs) {
   
   vector < float > derivative;
   
   derivative.resize(xs.size());
   
   for (int i = 0; i < xs.size(); i++) {
      derivative[i] = xs[i+1] - xs[i];
   }
   
   return derivative;
}

<|endoftext|>/*
Task
Write a function that takes a string as input and returns the sum of the upper characters only's
ASCII codes.

Examples:
    digitSum("") => 0
    digitSum("abAB") => 131
    digitSum("abcCd") => 67
    digitSum("helloE") => 69
    digitSum("woArBld") => 131
    digitSum("aAaaaXa") => 153
*/
#include <stdio.h>
#include <string>
using std;
int digitSum(string s) {
    int sum = 0;
   
    for (int i = 0; i < s.length(); i++) {
        sum += s.at(i) - 'A' + 1;
    }
    return sum;
}

<|endoftext|>/*
Filter an input vector of strings only for ones that contain given substring
>>> filter_by_substring({}, "a")
{}
>>> filter_by_substring({"abc", "bacd", "cde", "vector"}, "a")
{"abc", "bacd", "vector"}
*/
#include <stdio.h>
#include <vector>
#include <string>
using std;
vector < string > filter_by_substring(vector < string > strings, string substring) {
    vector < string > out;
   
    for (auto it = strings.begin(); it!= strings.end(); ++it) {
        if (it->find(substring)!= string::npos) {
            out.push_back(*it);
        }
    }
    return out;
}

<|endoftext|>/*
For a given vector of integers, return a vector consisting of a sum and a product of all the integers in a vector.
Empty sum should be equal to 0 and empty product should be equal to 1.
>>> sum_product({})
(0, 1)
>>> sum_product({1, 2, 3, 4})
(10, 24)
*/
#include <stdio.h>
#include <vector>
using std;
vector < int > sum_product(vector < int > numbers) {
    int sum = 0, product = 1;
    for (int Z = 0; Z < numbers.size(); Z++)
   
        sum = sum + numbers[Z];
    
    for (int Z = 0; Z < numbers.size(); Z++)
        product = product * numbers[Z];
    
    vector < int > result;
    result.push_back(sum);
    result.push_back(product);
    return result;
}

<|endoftext|>/*
Create a function encrypt that takes a string as an argument and
returns a string encrypted with the alphabet being rotated. 
The alphabet should be rotated in a manner such that the letters 
shift down by two multiplied to two places.
For example:
encrypt("hi") returns "lm"
encrypt("asdfghjkl") returns "ewhjklnop"
encrypt("gf") returns "kj"
encrypt("et") returns "ix"
*/
#include <stdio.h>
#include <string>
using std;
string encrypt(string s) {
    string out;
    int L;
   
    L = s.length();
    for(int i = 0; i < L; i++) {
        out[i] = s[L - 1 - i];
    }
    
    return out;
}
/*
Create a function decrypt that takes a string as an argument and
returns a string decrypted with the alphabet being rotated. 
The alphabet should be rotated in a manner such that the letters 
shift down by two multiplied to two places.
For example:
decrypt("lm") returns "hi"
decrypt("ewhjklnop") returns "asdfghjkl"
decrypt("kj") returns "gf"
decrypt("ix") returns "et"
*/
#include <stdio.h>
#include <string>
using std;
string decrypt(string s) {
    string out;
    int L;
   
    L = s.length();
    for(int i = 0; i < L; i++) {
        out[i] = s[L - 1 - i];
    }
    
    return out;
}

in the sequence.
>>> rolling_max({1, 2, 3, 2, 3, 4, 2})
{1, 2, 3, 3, 3, 4, 4}
*/
#include <stdio.h>
#include <vector>
using std;
vector < int > rolling_max(vector < int > numbers) {
    vector < int > out;
    int LH6 = 0;
   
    for(int i = 0; i < numbers.size(); i++) {
        if(numbers[i] > numbers[LH6]) {
            out.push_back(numbers[i]);
        }
        else {
            out.push_back(numbers[LH6]);
        }
        LH6 = i;
    }
    return out;
}
